document_title: Dried plum diet protects from bone loss caused by ionizing radiation
summary_full: Ionizing radiation, encountered by radiotherapy patients, radiation workers, and astronauts, can cause bone loss by increasing oxidative damage and promoting bone-resorbing osteoclasts. This study investigated the efficacy of various interventions, including an antioxidant cocktail, dihydrolipoic acid, ibuprofen, and dried plum (DP), in mitigating radiation-induced bone loss. Mice were exposed to gamma rays (2 Gy) or simulated space radiation (1 Gy protons and heavy ions). The DP diet was found to be the most effective intervention, significantly reducing the expression of genes related to bone resorption (Nfe2l2, Rankl, Mcp1, Opg, TNF-α) and preventing cancellous bone loss in both radiation models. Other interventions showed partial or no protective effects. The findings suggest that dietary supplementation with dried plum may be a viable strategy to prevent skeletal damage from radiation exposure.
key_findings: Dried plum (DP) diet effectively prevented bone loss caused by both gamma radiation and simulated space radiation.
DP diet reduced the expression of key genes involved in bone resorption (Nfe2l2, Rankl, Mcp1, Opg, TNF-α) following irradiation.
Other tested interventions, including an antioxidant cocktail, dihydrolipoic acid, and ibuprofen, were less effective or ineffective in preventing radiation-induced bone loss.
Radiation exposure increased oxidative stress markers (Nfe2l2) and pro-osteoclastogenic cytokines in bone marrow cells.
DP diet maintained cancellous bone structure (BV/TV, Tb.N, Tb.Sp) comparable to non-irradiated controls.
future_research_fields: Investigate the specific components within dried plum responsible for its radioprotective effects.
Determine the long-term effects of DP supplementation on bone mechanical properties after radiation exposure.
Evaluate the efficacy of DP in preventing microgravity-induced bone loss in the context of spaceflight.
Explore the synergistic effects of DP with other potential bone-protective agents.
Conduct clinical trials to assess the efficacy of DP in human populations exposed to radiation.

conclusions: Dietary supplementation with dried plum effectively prevents bone loss and preserves skeletal microarchitecture following exposure to both gamma radiation and simulated space radiation. This protective effect is associated with the mitigation of radiation-induced increases in pro-osteoclastogenic and oxidative stress-related gene expression in bone marrow cells.
impact_statement: This study identifies dried plum as a promising dietary intervention to protect against bone loss caused by ionizing radiation, relevant for astronauts, radiotherapy patients, and radiation workers.
